Comment: This game illustrates the power of the double bishops x-raying the opponent king's position. This is a sicilian opening game.

This knight move seeks to eliminate the white bishop after 10...Nd4. I was anticipating White will not take Knight with Knight because after 11...cxd4, his Knight on c3 will be attacked and has to move, making him lose tempo.

White weakened the position of his king. Maybe he was thinking of a pawn storm on Black's castled position but he does not realize that the attack on his king is very imminent.
This move was make the with DSB decide to take or to retreat.
White opts to lose the bishop pair.
Black has the advantage of the bishop pair which will be very strong later on.
White has weakened his hold of the dark squares making Black's DSB more ominous.

Perhaps White was concerned with exchanging his Knight for the DSB and having double pawns on the g-file. and he might have been planning to put his Queen on g4 threatening mate in 1. or he might have been thinking of moving his pawn to d4 which will greatly weaken black's position and/or eliminate Black's DSB at the expense of White's LSB biting on bricks.
